bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, December 7, 1927

div1.p: Kean mentions the dedication of Walter Reed's birthplace and ongoing yellow fever work. He offers his opinion on the Reed-Finlay debate.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, December 7, 1927
div1.opener:
7 December, 1927
Dr. Aristides Agramonte,
University of Havana,
Havana, Cuba.
My dear Dr. Agramonte:
div1.p:
I have been undity long in writing to thank you for your
publications with regard to the work of the Reed Board. The story has
always been of intense interest to me, and we cannot have too many
details or side lights with regard to it. Just after your letter
came I went down to Reed's birthplace to give an address at the
dedication of the little cottage in which he was born. I will
publish it in the January number of The Military Surgeon, and will
send you a copy. If there are any points of view which are not, in
your opinion, entirely accurate I would be glad to have your comment.

I am tremenduously interested in what you say about Noguchi's
Lepto spira. I have read a report of Sellard's work, and it seems to
me it is absolutely convincing. Major Callendar, who is our best
pathologist now in the army, thinks so too. I heard a rumor that the
Rockefeller working party in West Africa has succeeded in producing
experimental yellow fever in an Asiatic monkey, but this is not yet
ready for announcement or publication.

You will see that I discussed briefly the sensitiveness
that Dr. Le Roi and others of your compatriots have shown about the
credit that should be given to our dear friend, Dr. Finlay. I can
understand their jealousy for his fame because I feel the same way about
Walter Reed and try to hold the scales even; I think you do too.
Wishing you a very Happy New Year, I am
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J.R. KEAN,
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd. JRK/B
